results.title: I'm seventeen, I'm pregnant and I don't know what to do
results.creator_credit: Lee Mendelson Film Productions and David Crommie
results.brief_description: Dramatizes the plight of an unwed pregnant adolescent. With her parents, social workers and a discussion group at the Children’s Home Society of California, she considers the alternatives of abortion, forced marriage, temporary foster care, keeping the baby or relinquishing it for adoption.

results.title: I'm ready to learn
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Henry Lewes
results.brief_description: Pre-school education in Australia is examined. How important is pre-school education? Does a child really learn anything - or is it just a baby-sitting service, or a playtime? What kind of pre-school education is available and what are the requirements of an adequate pre-school education? How many children have a chance to receive this type of education and what happens to those who miss out on this opportunity?

results.title: I'm positive that's sugar
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre and Ross Campbell
results.brief_description: Intended for discussion use. This film to be used to introduce the new Primary Science course. Children are seen and heard as they classify and group various materials. Observations and “experiments” are carried out.

results.title: I'm not too famous at it: a definition of learning disabilities
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson, Barrie Angus McLean and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Learning Series”.
The title was named by Robert, a bright nine year old, who lacks eye-hand coordination, has difficulty appreciating the characteristics of shapes and forms, has language difficulties of various kinds, who has poor gross motor coordination and other problems. While defining and describing these learning deficits indirectly shows somthing of the process of remediation.

results.title: I'm No Fool with Fire (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Host, Jiminy Cricket, describes the three elements needed to start a fire and warns of ways fires can start through carelessness. This safety classic goes behind-the-scenes at a real fire station where a fire fighter helps three youngsters review fire safety procedures.
results.description: Host, Jiminy Cricket, describes the three elements needed to start a fire and warns of ways fires can start through carelessness. This safety classic goes behind-the-scenes at a real fire station where a fire fighter helps three youngsters review fire safety procedures.

results.title: I'm no fool with fire
results.brief_description: Jiminy Cricket shows how humans have depended on fire through the ages and describes the rules of fire safety, how to extinguish a fire and the most effective ways of fire prevention.
results.description: Jiminy Cricket shows how humans have depended on fire through the ages and describes the rules of fire safety, how to extinguish a fire and the most effective ways of fire prevention.

results.title: I'm no fool with a bicycle
results.brief_description: Jiminy Cricket traces the development of the bicycle from the hobby horse to the modern safety bicycle, and presents safety rules for riding a bicycle: keep both hands on the handle bars, both wheels on the ground and both feet on the pedals, and obey the same traffic rules as the driver of a car.
results.description: Jiminy Cricket traces the development of the bicycle from the hobby horse to the modern safety bicycle, and presents safety rules for riding a bicycle: keep both hands on the handle bars, both wheels on the ground and both feet on the pedals, and obey the same traffic rules as the driver of a car.

results.title: I'm no fool in water (K)
results.brief_description: Jiminy Cricket tells something of the history of swimming as a sport and goes on to describe the safety rules for swimming. Among these are the right and wrong places to swim, the chief water hazards, the need to wait two hours after eating and to swim in company.

results.title: I'm no fool having fun
results.brief_description: Jiminy Cricket explains how the human race has always needed play, recreation and fun. He contrasts unsafe play areas such as excavations, streets, new constructions or abandoned buildings, with safe areas, such as playgrounds, parks, one’s own backyard. Safety in various recreations, hiking, swimming, cycling, skating and sailing. Warns against showing off or getting overtired - a tired person is a careless one. Only a “common ordinary fool” violates the safety rules.
